# Catholic Church in England and Wales

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Not to be confused with [Catholic Church in the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_United_Kingdom "Catholic Church in the
United Kingdom").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/25px-
Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg)  
Catholic Church in England and Wales  
---

Cathedral"), [London](/wiki/London "London")

[Polity](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_polity "Ecclesiastical polity") | [Episcopal](/wiki/Episcopal_polity "Episcopal polity")  
[Pope](/wiki/Pope "Pope") | [Pope Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis")  
[Archbishop](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Westminster "Archbishop of Westminster") | [Vincent Nichols](/wiki/Vincent_Nichols "Vincent Nichols")

The **Catholic Church in England and Wales** is part of the worldwide
[Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") in [full
communion](/wiki/Full_communion "Full communion") with the [Pope](/wiki/Pope
"Pope"). [Celtic Christianity](/wiki/Celtic_Christianity "Celtic
Christianity"), with some traditions different from those of Rome, was present
in [Roman Britain](/wiki/Roman_Britain "Roman Britain") from the first century
AD, but after the departure of the Roman legions was in retreat to
[Paganism](/wiki/Paganism "Paganism"). In 597 AD, the first authoritative
papal mission, establishing a direct link from the [Kingdom of
Kent](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kent "Kingdom of Kent") to the [See of
Rome](/wiki/See_of_Rome "See of Rome") and to the
[Benedictine](/wiki/Benedictine "Benedictine") form of
[monasticism](/wiki/Monasticism "Monasticism"), was carried into effect by
[Augustine of Canterbury](/wiki/Augustine_of_Canterbury "Augustine of
Canterbury").

The English Church continuously adhered to the See of Rome for almost a
thousand years from the time of Augustine of Canterbury, but in 1534, during
the reign of [King Henry VIII](/wiki/King_Henry_VIII "King Henry VIII"), the
church, through a series of legislative acts between 1533 and 1536[1] became
independent from the Pope for a period as the [Church of
England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England"), a national church with
Henry declaring himself Supreme Head.[2][3][4] Under Henry's son, [King Edward
VI](/wiki/King_Edward_VI "King Edward VI"), the Church of England became more
influenced by the European [Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant")
movement.

The English Church was brought back under full papal authority in 1553, at the
beginning of the reign of [Queen Mary I](/wiki/Mary_I_of_England "Mary I of
England"),[5] and Catholicism was enforced by the [Marian
persecutions](/wiki/Marian_persecutions "Marian persecutions"); however, when
[Queen Elizabeth I](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_I "Queen Elizabeth I") came to the
throne in 1558, the Church of England's independence from Rome was reasserted
through the [settlement of 1559](/wiki/Elizabethan_Religious_Settlement
"Elizabethan Religious Settlement"), which shifted the Church of England's
teaching and practice, and in the [Act of
Uniformity](/wiki/Act_of_Uniformity_1558 "Act of Uniformity 1558"), which
caused a rift between Catholics and Queen.[6] In 1570 [Pope Pius
V](/wiki/Pope_Pius_V "Pope Pius V") responded, in his bull _[Regnans in
Excelsis](/wiki/Regnans_in_Excelsis "Regnans in Excelsis")_ , calling on all
Catholics to rebel against Elizabeth and excommunicating anyone who obeyed
her. The [Parliament of England](/wiki/Parliament_of_England "Parliament of
England") made the fact of being a Jesuit or seminarian treasonable in 1571.
Priests found celebrating Mass were often [hanged, drawn and
quartered](/wiki/Hanged,_drawn_and_quartered "Hanged, drawn and quartered"),
rather than being burned at the stake.[7] The Catholic Church (along with
other non-established churches) continued in England, although it was at times
subject to various forms of persecution. Most [recusant](/wiki/Recusant
"Recusant") members (except those in diaspora on [the
Continent](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe"), in heavily Catholic
areas in the north, or part of the aristocracy) practised their faith in
private for all practical purposes. In 1766, the Pope recognised the English
Monarchy as lawful, and this led eventually to the [Roman Catholic Relief Act
1829](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Relief_Act_1829 "Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829").
[Dioceses](/wiki/Diocese "Diocese") (replacing districts) were re-established
by [Pope Pius IX](/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX "Pope Pius IX") in 1850. Along with the
22 [Latin Rite](/wiki/Latin_Rite "Latin Rite") dioceses, there are the
[Eastern Catholic](/wiki/Eastern_Catholic "Eastern Catholic") diocese of the
[Ukrainian Catholic Eparchy of Holy Family of
London](/wiki/Ukrainian_Catholic_Eparchy_of_Holy_Family_of_London "Ukrainian
Catholic Eparchy of Holy Family of London") and the [Syro-Malabar Catholic
Eparchy of Great Britain](/wiki/Syro-Malabar_Catholic_Eparchy_of_Great_Britain
"Syro-Malabar Catholic Eparchy of Great Britain").

At the 2001 United Kingdom census, there were 4.2 million Catholics in England
and Wales, some eight per cent of the population. One hundred years earlier,
in 1901, they represented only 4.8 per cent of the population. In 1981, 8.7
per cent of the population of England and Wales were Catholic.[8] In 2009, an
Ipsos Mori poll found that 9.6 per cent, or 5.2 million persons of all
ethnicities were Catholic in England and Wales.[9] Sizeable populations
include [North West England](/wiki/North_West_England "North West England")
where one in five is Catholic,[10] a result of large-scale [Irish
immigration](/wiki/Irish_immigration_to_Britain "Irish immigration to
Britain") in the nineteenth century[11][12] as well as the high number of
English [recusants](/wiki/Recusant "Recusant") in
[Lancashire](/wiki/Lancashire "Lancashire").

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Main article: [History of Christianity in
Britain](/wiki/History_of_Christianity_in_Britain "History of Christianity in
Britain")

### Roman Britons and early
Christianity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Roman Britons and early Christianity")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Saint_Alban_%28cropped%29.jpg/200px-
Saint_Alban_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Saint_Alban_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Saint_Alban_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

[St. Alban](/wiki/St._Alban "St. Alban") is regarded as the
[protomartyr](/wiki/Protomartyr "Protomartyr") of the Roman Britons.

Much of [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain") was incorporated
into the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") in 43 AD, after
[Claudius](/wiki/Claudius "Claudius") led the [Roman conquest of
Britain](/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Britain "Roman conquest of Britain"),
conquering lands inhabited by [Celtic Britons](/wiki/Celtic_Britons "Celtic
Britons"). The indigenous religious traditions of the Britons, under their
priests the [Druids](/wiki/Druids "Druids") were suppressed; most notably
[Gaius Suetonius Paulinus](/wiki/Gaius_Suetonius_Paulinus "Gaius Suetonius
Paulinus") launched [an attack](/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Anglesey "Roman
conquest of Anglesey") on [Ynys Môn](/wiki/Anglesey "Anglesey") in 60 AD and
destroyed the shrine and [sacred groves](/wiki/Sacred_groves "Sacred groves")
there. In the years following this, Roman influence saw the importation of
several religious [cults](/wiki/Cult_\(religious_practice\) "Cult \(religious
practice\)") into Britain, including [Roman mythology](/wiki/Roman_mythology
"Roman mythology"), [Mithraism](/wiki/Mithraism "Mithraism") and the [imperial
cult](/wiki/Imperial_cult "Imperial cult"). One of these sects, then
disapproved by the Roman authorities, was the [Levantine](/wiki/Levant
"Levant")-originated religion of [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity
"Christianity"). While it is unclear exactly how it arrived, the earliest
British figures considered [saints](/wiki/Saint "Saint") by the Christians are
[St. Alban](/wiki/St._Alban "St. Alban"), followed by Ss. [Julius and
Aaron](/wiki/Julius_and_Aaron "Julius and Aaron"), living in the 3rd
century.[13]

Eventually, the position of the Roman authorities on Christianity moved from
hostility, to toleration with the [Edict of Milan](/wiki/Edict_of_Milan "Edict
of Milan") in 313 AD and then enforcement as [state
religion](/wiki/State_religion "State religion") following the [Edict of
Thessalonica](/wiki/Edict_of_Thessalonica "Edict of Thessalonica") in 380 AD,
becoming a key component of [Romano-British culture](/wiki/Romano-
British_culture "Romano-British culture") and society. Records note that
[Romano-British](/wiki/Romano-British "Romano-British") bishops, such as
[Restitutus](/wiki/Restitutus "Restitutus"), attended the [Council of
Arles](/wiki/Council_of_Arles "Council of Arles") in 314, which confirmed the
theological findings of an earlier convocation held in Rome (the [Council of
Rome](/wiki/Council_of_Rome "Council of Rome")) in 313. The [Roman departure
from Britain](/wiki/Roman_departure_from_Britain "Roman departure from
Britain") in the following century and the subsequent [Germanic
invasions](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_invasion_of_Britain "Anglo-Saxon invasion of
Britain") sharply decreased contact between Britain and Continental Europe.
Christianity, however, continued to flourish in the
[Brittonic](/wiki/Britons_\(historical\) "Britons \(historical\)") areas of
Great Britain. During this period certain practices and traditions took hold
in Britain and in Ireland that are collectively known as [Celtic
Christianity](/wiki/Celtic_Christianity "Celtic Christianity"). Distinct
features of Celtic Christianity include a unique monastic
[tonsure](/wiki/Tonsure "Tonsure") and calculations for the date of
[Easter](/wiki/Easter "Easter").[14] Regardless of these differences,
historians do not consider this Celtic or British Christianity a distinct
church separate from general Western European Christianity.[15][16]

### Conversion of the Anglo-
Saxons[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Conversion of the Anglo-Saxons")]

In 597, [Pope Gregory I](/wiki/Pope_Gregory_I "Pope Gregory I") sent
[Augustine of Canterbury](/wiki/Augustine_of_Canterbury "Augustine of
Canterbury") and 40 missionaries from Rome to evangelise the [Anglo-
Saxons](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons"), a process completed by the 7th
century. The [Gregorian mission](/wiki/Gregorian_mission "Gregorian mission"),
as it is known, is of particular interest in the Catholic Church as it was the
first official Papal mission to found a church. With the help of Christians
already residing in [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent"), Augustine established an
archbishopric in [Canterbury](/wiki/Canterbury "Canterbury"), the old capital
of Kent, and, having received the [pallium](/wiki/Pallium "Pallium") earlier
(linking his new diocese to Rome), became the first in the series of Catholic
[archbishops of Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishops_of_Canterbury "Archbishops of
Canterbury"), four of whom ([Laurence](/wiki/Laurence_of_Canterbury "Laurence
of Canterbury"), [Mellitus](/wiki/Mellitus "Mellitus"), [Justus](/wiki/Justus
"Justus") and [Honorius](/wiki/Honorius_of_Canterbury "Honorius of
Canterbury")) were part of the original band of
[Benedictine](/wiki/Benedictine "Benedictine") missionaries. (The last
Catholic archbishop of Canterbury was [Reginald Pole](/wiki/Reginald_Pole
"Reginald Pole"), who died in 1558.) During this time of mission, Rome pursued
greater unity with the local church in Britain, particularly on the question
of dating Easter. [Columbanus](/wiki/Columbanus "Columbanus"), Columba's
fellow countryman and churchman, had asked for a papal judgement on the Easter
question as did abbots and bishops of Ireland.[17] Later, in his _Historia
ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum_ , Bede explained the reasons for the
discrepancy: "He [Columba] left successors distinguished for great charity,
Divine love, and strict attention to the rules of discipline following indeed
uncertain cycles in the computation of the great festival of Easter, because
far away as they were out of the world, no one had supplied them with the
synodal decrees relating to the Paschal observance."[18] A series of
[synods](/wiki/Synod "Synod") were held to resolve the matter, culminating
with the [Synod of Whitby](/wiki/Synod_of_Whitby "Synod of Whitby") in 644.
The missionaries also introduced the [Rule of Benedict](/wiki/Rule_of_Benedict
"Rule of Benedict"), the continental rule, to Anglo-Saxon monasteries in
England.[19] [Wilfrid](/wiki/Wilfrid "Wilfrid"), a Benedictine consecrated
archbishop of York (in 664), was particularly skilled in promoting the
Benedictine Rule.[20] Over time, the Benedictine, continental rule engrafted
upon the monasteries and parishes of England, drawing them closer to The
Continent and Rome. As a result, the pope was often called upon to intervene
in quarrels, affirm monarchs, and decide jurisdictions. In 787, for example,
[Pope Adrian I](/wiki/Pope_Adrian_I "Pope Adrian I") elevated
[Lichfield](/wiki/Lichfield "Lichfield") to an archdiocese and appointed
[Hygeberht](/wiki/Hygeberht "Hygeberht") its first archbishop.[21] Later, in
808, [Pope Leo III](/wiki/Pope_Leo_III "Pope Leo III") helped restore King
[Eardwulf](/wiki/Eardwulf "Eardwulf") of [Northumbria](/wiki/Northumbria
"Northumbria") to his throne; and in 859, [Pope Leo IV](/wiki/Pope_Leo_IV
"Pope Leo IV") confirmed and anointed [Alfred the
Great](/wiki/Alfred_the_Great "Alfred the Great") king, according to _[Anglo-
Saxon Chronicle](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Chronicle "Anglo-Saxon Chronicle")_.
Individual Benedictines seemed to play an important role throughout this
period. For example, before Benedictine monk [St. Dunstan](/wiki/St._Dunstan
"St. Dunstan") was consecrated archbishop of Canterbury in 960, [Pope John
XII](/wiki/Pope_John_XII "Pope John XII") had him appointed legate,
commissioning him (along with [Ethelwold](/wiki/Ethelwold "Ethelwold") and
Oswald) to restore discipline in the existing monasteries of England, many of
which were destroyed by Danish invaders.[22]

### Norman Church in England and
Wales[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Norman Church in England and Wales")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Our_Lady_of_Walsingham_detail_I.JPG/220px-
Our_Lady_of_Walsingham_detail_I.JPG)](/wiki/File:Our_Lady_of_Walsingham_detail_I.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Our_Lady_of_Walsingham_detail_I.JPG "Enlarge")

[Our Lady of Walsingham](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Walsingham "Our Lady of
Walsingham")

Control of the English Church passed from the Anglo-Saxons to the
[Normans](/wiki/Normans "Normans") following the [Norman conquest of
England](/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England "Norman conquest of England"). The
two clerics most prominent associated with this process were the continental-
born [Lanfranc](/wiki/Lanfranc "Lanfranc") and
[Anselm](/wiki/Anselm_of_Canterbury "Anselm of Canterbury"); both men were
Benedictines. Anselm later became a [Doctor of the
Church](/wiki/Doctor_of_the_Church "Doctor of the Church"). A century later,
[Pope Innocent III](/wiki/Pope_Innocent_III "Pope Innocent III") had to
confirm the primacy of Canterbury over four [Welsh](/wiki/Wales "Wales")
churches for many reasons, but primarily to sustain the importance of the
Gregorian foundation of Augustine's mission.[23][24]

During mediaeval times, England and Wales were part of western Christendom.
During this period, monasteries and convents, such as those at
[Shaftesbury](/wiki/Shaftesbury_Abbey "Shaftesbury Abbey") and
[Shrewsbury](/wiki/Shrewsbury_Abbey "Shrewsbury Abbey"), were prominent
features of society providing lodging, hospitals and education.[25] Likewise,
schools like [Oxford University](/wiki/Oxford_University "Oxford University")
and [Cambridge University](/wiki/Cambridge_University "Cambridge University")
were important. Members of [religious orders](/wiki/Religious_orders
"Religious orders"), notably the [Dominicans](/wiki/Dominican_Order "Dominican
Order") and [Franciscans](/wiki/Franciscans "Franciscans"), settled in both
schools and maintained houses for students. Clerics like Archbishop [Walter de
Merton](/wiki/Walter_de_Merton "Walter de Merton") founded [Merton
College](/wiki/Merton_College "Merton College") at Oxford and three different
popes – [Gregory IX](/wiki/Gregory_IX "Gregory IX"), [Nicholas
IV](/wiki/Pope_Nicholas_IV "Pope Nicholas IV"), and [John
XXII](/wiki/John_XXII "John XXII") – gave Cambridge the legal protection and
status to compete with other European [medieval
universities](/wiki/Medieval_universities "Medieval universities").

Pilgrimage was a prominent feature of mediaeval Catholicism, and England and
Wales were amply provided with many popular sites of pilgrimage. The village
of [Walsingham](/wiki/Walsingham "Walsingham"), Norfolk became an important
shrine after a noblewoman called [Richeldis de
Faverches](/wiki/Richeldis_de_Faverches "Richeldis de Faverches") experienced
a vision of the Virgin Mary in 1061, asking her to build a replica of the
[Holy House](/w/index.php?title=Holy_House&action=edit&redlink=1 "Holy House
\(page does not exist\)") at [Nazareth](/wiki/Nazareth "Nazareth"). In 1170,
[Thomas Becket](/wiki/Thomas_Becket "Thomas Becket"), Archbishop of Canterbury
was murdered in Canterbury Cathedral, by followers of [King Henry
II](/wiki/Henry_II_of_England "Henry II of England") and was quickly canonised
as a martyr for the faith. This resulted in Canterbury becoming a major place
of pilgrimage and inspired the [Canterbury Tales](/wiki/Canterbury_Tales
"Canterbury Tales") by [Geoffrey Chaucer](/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer "Geoffrey
Chaucer"). There were also shrines at [Holywell](/wiki/Holywell "Holywell") in
Wales which commemorated St [Winefride](/wiki/Winefride "Winefride") and at
Westminster Abbey to [Edward the Confessor](/wiki/Edward_the_Confessor "Edward
the Confessor") to name but a few.

An Englishman, Nicholas Breakspear, became [Pope Adrian
IV](/wiki/Pope_Adrian_IV "Pope Adrian IV"), ruling from 1154 to 1159. Fifty-
six years later, [Cardinal](/wiki/Cardinal_\(Catholicism\) "Cardinal
\(Catholicism\)") [Stephen Langton](/wiki/Stephen_Langton "Stephen Langton"),
the first of [English cardinals](/wiki/English_cardinals "English cardinals")
and later Archbishop of Canterbury (1208–28), became a pivotal figure in the
dispute between [King John](/wiki/John_of_England "John of England") and [Pope
Innocent III](/wiki/Pope_Innocent_III "Pope Innocent III"). This critical
situation led to the signing and later promulgation of the [Magna
Charta](/wiki/Magna_Charta "Magna Charta") in 1215.

### Protestantism and Catholic
Resistance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Protestantism and Catholic Resistance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Banner_of_the_Holy_Wounds_%28Pilgrimage_of_Grace%29.svg/200px-
Banner_of_the_Holy_Wounds_%28Pilgrimage_of_Grace%29.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Banner_of_the_Holy_Wounds_\(Pilgrimage_of_Grace\).svg)

[](/wiki/File:Banner_of_the_Holy_Wounds_\(Pilgrimage_of_Grace\).svg "Enlarge")

A banner showing the [Holy Wounds](/wiki/Holy_Wounds "Holy Wounds") of [Jesus
Christ](/wiki/Jesus_Christ "Jesus Christ") which was carried by partisans
during the [Pilgrimage of Grace](/wiki/Pilgrimage_of_Grace "Pilgrimage of
Grace").

England remained a Catholic country until 1534, when it first officially
separated from Rome during the reign of [King Henry
VIII](/wiki/King_Henry_VIII "King Henry VIII"). In response to the Pope's
refusal to annul Henry's marriage to [Catherine of
Aragon](/wiki/Catherine_of_Aragon "Catherine of Aragon"), Parliament denied
the Pope's authority over the English Church, made the king Head of the Church
in England, and dissolved the monasteries and religious orders in England.
Henry did not himself accept [Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant")
innovations in doctrine or liturgy – but he extended toleration, and even
promotion, to clergy with Protestant sympathies in return for support for his
break with Rome. On the other hand, failure to accept this break, particularly
by prominent persons in church and state, was regarded by Henry as treason,
resulting in the execution of [Thomas More](/wiki/Thomas_More "Thomas More"),
former Lord Chancellor, and [John Fisher](/wiki/John_Fisher "John Fisher"),
[Bishop of Rochester](/wiki/Bishop_of_Rochester "Bishop of Rochester"), among
others. The [See of Rome Act 1536](/wiki/See_of_Rome_Act_1536 "See of Rome Act
1536") enforced the separation from Rome, while the '[Pilgrimage of
Grace](/wiki/Pilgrimage_of_Grace "Pilgrimage of Grace")' of 1536 and '[Bigod's
Rebellion](/wiki/Bigod%27s_Rebellion "Bigod's Rebellion")' of 1537, risings in
the North against the religious changes, were bloodily repressed.

In 1536-41 Henry VIII engaged in a large-scale [Dissolution of the
Monasteries](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Monasteries "Dissolution of the
Monasteries"), which controlled most of the wealth of the church, and much of
the richest land. He disbanded [monasteries](/wiki/Monasteries "Monasteries"),
[priories](/wiki/Priory "Priory"), [convents](/wiki/Convent "Convent") and
[friaries](/wiki/Friaries "Friaries") in England, Wales and Ireland,
appropriated their income, disposed of their assets, and provided pensions for
the former residents. He did not turn these properties over to a Protestant
church of England (which indeed did not yet exist): they were sold, mostly to
pay for the wars. The historian G. W. Bernard argues:

    The dissolution of the monasteries in the late 1530s was one of the most revolutionary events in English history. There were nearly 900 religious houses in England, around 260 for monks, 300 for regular canons, 142 nunneries and 183 friaries; some 12,000 people in total, 4,000 monks, 3,000 canons, 3,000 friars and 2,000 nuns....one adult man in fifty was in religious orders.[26]

Nevertheless, Henry maintained a strong preference for traditional Catholic
practices and, during his reign, Protestant reformers were unable to make many
changes to the practices of the Church of England. Indeed, this part of
Henry's reign saw the trial for heresy of Protestants as well as Catholics.

The 1547 to 1553 reign of the boy [King Edward VI](/wiki/King_Edward_VI "King
Edward VI") saw the Church of England become more influenced by Protestantism
in its faith and worship, with the (Latin) [Mass](/wiki/Mass "Mass") replaced
by the (English) [Book of Common Prayer](/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer "Book of
Common Prayer"), representational art and statues in church buildings
destroyed, and Catholic practices which had survived during Henry's reign, for
instance the public saying of prayers to the Virgin Mary such as the [Salve
Regina](/wiki/Salve_Regina "Salve Regina"), ended. The Western Rising took
place in 1549.

The institutional Church in England returned to Catholic practice during the
reign of the Catholic [Queen Mary I](/wiki/Mary_I_of_England "Mary I of
England") from 1553 to 1558. Mary was determined to bring back the whole of
England to the Catholic faith. This aim was not necessarily at odds with the
feeling of a large section of the populace; Edward's Protestant reformation
had not been well received everywhere, and there was ambiguity in the
responses of the parishes.[27] Mary also had some powerful families behind
her. The Jerningham family together with other East Anglian Catholic families
such as the Bedingfelds, Waldegraves, Rochesters together with the Huddlestons
of Sawston Hall were "the key to Queen Mary's successful accession to the
throne. Without them she would never have made it."[28] However, Mary's
executions of 300 Protestants by burning at the stake proved
counterproductive, as they were extremely unpopular among the populace. For
example, instead of executing Archbishop Cranmer for treason for supporting
[Queen Jane](/wiki/Lady_Jane_Grey "Lady Jane Grey"), she had him tried for
heresy and burned at a stake.[29][30] With the assistance of _[Foxe's Book of
Martyrs](/wiki/Foxe%27s_Book_of_Martyrs "Foxe's Book of Martyrs")_, which
glorified the Protestants killed at the time and vilified Catholics,[31] this
practice ensured her a place in popular memory as _Bloody Mary_ – for
centuries after the idea of another reconciliation with Rome was linked in
many English people's minds with a renewal of Mary's fiery stakes.

When Mary died and [Elizabeth I](/wiki/Elizabeth_I "Elizabeth I") became queen
in 1558, the religious situation in England was confused. Throughout the see-
sawing religious landscape of the reigns of Henry VIII, Edward VI, and Mary I,
a significant proportion of the population (especially in the rural and
outlying areas of the country), are likely to have continued to hold Catholic
views, at least in private. By the end of Elizabeth I's reign, however,
England was clearly a Protestant country, and Catholics were a minority.

Elizabeth's first act was to reverse her sister's re-establishment of
Catholicism by [Acts of Supremacy and
Uniformity](/wiki/Elizabethan_Religious_Settlement "Elizabethan Religious
Settlement"). [The Act of Supremacy of 1558](/wiki/Act_of_Supremacy_1558 "Act
of Supremacy 1558") made it a crime to assert the authority of any foreign
prince, [prelate](/wiki/Prelate "Prelate"), or other authority, and was aimed
at abolishing the authority of the [Pope](/wiki/Pope "Pope") in England. A
third offence was [high treason](/wiki/High_treason "High treason"),
punishable by death. The [Oath of Supremacy](/wiki/Oath_of_Supremacy "Oath of
Supremacy"), imposed by the Act of Supremacy 1558, provided for any person
taking public or church office in [England](/wiki/England "England") to swear
allegiance to the monarch as [Supreme Governor](/wiki/Supreme_Governor
"Supreme Governor") of the [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church
of England"). Failure to so swear was a crime, although it did not become
treason until 1562, when the **Supremacy of the Crown Act 1562**[32] made a
second offence of refusing to take the oath treason.

However, during the first years of her reign there was relative leniency
towards Catholics who were willing to keep their religion private, especially
if they were prepared to continue to attend their parish churches. The wording
of the official prayer book had been carefully designed to make this possible
by omitting aggressively "heretical" matter, and at first many English
Catholics did in fact worship with their Protestant neighbours, at least until
this was formally forbidden by [Pope Pius V](/wiki/Pope_Pius_V "Pope Pius
V")'s 1570 bull, _[Regnans in Excelsis](/wiki/Regnans_in_Excelsis "Regnans in
Excelsis")_ , which also declared that Elizabeth was not a rightful queen and
should be deposed, formally excommunicated her and any who obeyed her and
obliged all Catholics to attempt to overthrow her.[33]

In response, the "Act to retain the Queen's Majesty's subjects in their
obedience", passed in 1581, made it high treason to reconcile anyone or to be
reconciled to "the Romish religion", or to procure or publish any papal Bull
or writing whatsoever. The celebration of mass was prohibited under penalty of
a fine of two hundred marks and imprisonment for one year for the celebrant,
and a fine of one hundred marks and the same imprisonment for those who heard
the Mass. This act also increased the penalty for not attending the Anglican
service to the sum of twenty pounds a month, or imprisonment till the fine be
paid, or till the offender went to the Protestant Church. A further penalty of
ten pounds a month was inflicted on anyone keeping a schoolmaster who did not
attend the Protestant service. The schoolmaster himself was to be imprisoned
for one year.[34]

In the setting of England's wars with Catholic powers such as France and
Spain, culminating in the attempted invasion by the [Spanish
Armada](/wiki/Spanish_Armada "Spanish Armada") in 1588, the Papal bull
unleashed a nationalistic feeling which equated Protestantism with loyalty to
a highly popular monarch, rendering every Catholic a potential traitor, even
in the eyes of those who were not themselves extreme Protestants. The [Rising
of the North](/wiki/Rising_of_the_North "Rising of the North"), the
[Throckmorton plot](/wiki/Throckmorton_plot "Throckmorton plot") and the
[Babington plot](/wiki/Babington_plot "Babington plot"), together with other
subversive activities of supporters of [Mary, Queen of
Scots](/wiki/Mary,_Queen_of_Scots "Mary, Queen of Scots"), all reinforced the
association of Catholicism and treachery in the popular mind.

The climax of Elizabeth's persecution of Catholics was reached in 1585 by the
"[Act against Jesuits, Seminary priests and other such like disobedient
persons](/wiki/Act_against_Jesuits,_Seminary_priests_and_other_such_like_disobedient_persons
"Act against Jesuits, Seminary priests and other such like disobedient
persons")". This statute, under which most of the [English Catholic
martyrs](/wiki/List_of_Catholic_martyrs_of_the_English_Reformation "List of
Catholic martyrs of the English Reformation") were executed, made it high
treason for any Jesuit or any seminary priest to be in England at all, and
felony for any one to harbour or relieve them.

The last of Elizabeth's anti-Catholic laws was the "Act for the better
discovery of wicked and seditious persons terming themselves Catholics, but
being rebellious and traitorous subjects". Its effect was to prohibit all
[recusants](/wiki/Recusants "Recusants") from removing more than five miles
from their place of abode, and to order all persons suspected of being Jesuits
or seminary priests, and not answering satisfactorily, to be imprisoned till
they did so.[35]

However, Elizabeth did not believe that her anti-Catholic policies constituted
religious persecution, finding it hard, in the context of the uncompromising
wording of the Papal Bull against her, to distinguish between those Catholics
engaged in conflict with her from those Catholics with no such designs.[36]
The number of English Catholics executed under Elizabeth was significant,
including [Edmund Campion](/wiki/Edmund_Campion "Edmund Campion"), [Robert
Southwell](/wiki/Robert_Southwell_\(jesuit\) "Robert Southwell \(jesuit\)"),
and [Margaret Clitherow](/wiki/Margaret_Clitherow "Margaret Clitherow").
Elizabeth herself signed the death warrant that led to
[regicide](/wiki/Regicide "Regicide"), the beheading of her cousin, Mary,
Queen of Scots.

Because of the persecution in England, Catholic priests in England were
trained abroad at the [English College in Rome](/wiki/English_College "English
College"), the [English College in Douai](/wiki/English_College,_Douai
"English College, Douai"), the [English College at Valladolid in
Spain](/wiki/English_College,_Valladolid "English College, Valladolid"), and
at the English College in Seville. Given that Douai was located in the
[Spanish Netherlands](/wiki/Spanish_Netherlands "Spanish Netherlands"), part
of the dominions of Elizabethan England's greatest enemy, and Valladolid and
Seville in Spain itself, they became associated in the public eye with
political as well as religious subversion. It was this combination of
nationalistic public opinion, sustained persecution, and the rise of a new
generation which could not remember pre-Reformation times and had no pre-
established loyalty to Catholicism, that reduced the number of Catholics in
England during this period – although the overshadowing memory of Queen Mary
I's reign was another factor that should not be underestimated. Nevertheless,
by the end of the reign probably 20% of the population were still Catholic,
with another 10% dissident "Puritan" Protestants, and the remainder more or
less reconciled to the "official" church.

The reign of [James I](/wiki/James_I_of_England "James I of England")
(1603–1625) was marked by a measure of tolerance, though less so after the
discovery of the [Gunpowder Plot](/wiki/Gunpowder_Plot "Gunpowder Plot")
conspiracy of a small group of Catholic conspirators who aimed to kill both
King and Parliament and establish a Catholic monarchy. A mix of persecution
and tolerance followed: [Ben Jonson](/wiki/Ben_Jonson "Ben Jonson") and his
wife, for example, in 1606 were summoned before the authorities for failure to
take communion in the Church of England,[37] yet the King tolerated some
Catholics at court; for example George Calvert, to whom he gave the title
[Baron Baltimore](/wiki/Baron_Baltimore "Baron Baltimore"), and the [Duke of
Norfolk](/wiki/Duke_of_Norfolk "Duke of Norfolk"), head of the [Howard
family](/wiki/Howard_family "Howard family").

The reign of [Charles I](/wiki/Charles_I_of_England "Charles I of England")
(1625–49) saw a small revival of Catholicism in England, especially among the
upper classes. As part of the royal marriage settlement Charles's Catholic
wife, [Henrietta Maria](/wiki/Henrietta_Maria "Henrietta Maria"), was
permitted her own royal chapel and chaplain. Henrietta Maria was in fact very
strict in her religious observances, and helped create a court with
continental influences, where Catholicism was tolerated, even somewhat
fashionable. Some anti-Catholic legislation became effectively a dead letter.
The [Counter-Reformation](/wiki/Counter-Reformation "Counter-Reformation") on
the Continent of Europe had created a more vigorous and magnificent form of
Catholicism (i.e., [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque"), notably found in the
architecture and music of Austria, Italy and Germany) that attracted some
converts, like the poet [Richard Crashaw](/wiki/Richard_Crashaw "Richard
Crashaw"). Ironically, the explicitly Catholic artistic movement (i.e.,
Baroque) ended up "providing the blueprint, after the fire of London, for the
first new Protestant churches to be built in England."[38]

While Charles remained firmly Protestant, he was personally drawn towards a
consciously 'High Church' Anglicanism. This affected his appointments to
Anglican bishoprics, in particular the appointment of [William
Laud](/wiki/William_Laud "William Laud") as [Archbishop of
Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury "Archbishop of Canterbury"). How
many Catholics and Puritans there were is still open to debate.[39][40]

Religious conflict between Charles and other "High" Anglicans and
[Calvinists](/wiki/Calvinists "Calvinists") \- at this stage mostly still
within the Church of England (the [Puritans](/wiki/Puritans "Puritans")) -
formed a strand of the anti-monarchical leanings of the troubled politics of
the period. The religious tensions between a court with 'Papist' elements and
a Parliament where the Puritans were strong was one of the major factors
behind the [English Civil War](/wiki/English_Civil_War "English Civil War"),
in which almost all Catholics supported the King. The victory of the
Parliamentarians meant a strongly Protestant, anti-Catholic (and,
incidentally, anti-Anglican) regime under [Oliver
Cromwell](/wiki/Oliver_Cromwell "Oliver Cromwell").

The restoration of the monarchy under [Charles II](/wiki/Charles_II_of_England
"Charles II of England") (1660–85) also saw the restoration of a Catholic-
influenced court like his father's. However, although Charles himself had
Catholic leanings, he was first and foremost a pragmatist and realised the
vast majority of public opinion in England was strongly anti-Catholic, so he
agreed to laws such as the Test Act requiring any appointee to any public
office or member of Parliament to deny Catholic beliefs such as
[transubstantiation](/wiki/Transubstantiation "Transubstantiation"). As far as
possible, however, he maintained tacit tolerance. Like his father, he married
a Catholic, [Catherine of Braganza](/wiki/Catherine_of_Braganza "Catherine of
Braganza"). (He would become Catholic himself on his deathbed).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/James_II_%28Ann_Killigrew%29.jpg/190px-
James_II_%28Ann_Killigrew%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:James_II_\(Ann_Killigrew\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:James_II_\(Ann_Killigrew\).jpg "Enlarge")

[James II](/wiki/James_II_of_England "James II of England") was the last
Catholic to have reigned as monarch of England.

Charles' brother and heir James, Duke of York (later [James
II](/wiki/James_II_of_England "James II of England")) converted to Catholicism
in 1668–1669. When [Titus Oates](/wiki/Titus_Oates "Titus Oates") in 1678
alleged a (totally imaginary) '[Popish Plot](/wiki/Popish_Plot "Popish Plot")'
to assassinate Charles and put James in his place, he unleashed a wave of
Parliamentary and public hysteria which led to anti-Catholic purges, and
another wave of sectarian persecution, which Charles was either unable or
unwilling to prevent. Throughout the early 1680s the
[Whig](/wiki/British_Whig_Party "British Whig Party") element in Parliament
attempted to remove James as successor to the throne. Their failure saw James
become, in 1685, Britain's first openly Catholic monarch since [Mary
I](/wiki/Mary_I_of_England "Mary I of England") (and last to date). He
promised religious toleration for Catholic and Protestants on an equal
footing, but it is in doubt whether he did this to gain support from
[Dissenters](/wiki/Dissenters "Dissenters") or whether he was truly committed
to tolerance (Contemporary Catholic regimes in Spain and Italy, for example,
were hardly tolerant of Protestantism, while those in France and Poland had
practised forms of toleration).[41][42]

James' clear intent to work towards the restoration of the Church of England
to the Catholic fold encouraged converts like the poet [John
Dryden](/wiki/John_Dryden "John Dryden"), who wrote "[The Hind and the
Panther](/wiki/The_Hind_and_the_Panther "The Hind and the Panther")",
celebrating his conversion.[43][44] Protestant fears mounted as James placed
Catholics in the major commands of the existing standing army, dismissed the
Protestant Bishop of London and dismissed the Protestant Fellows of Magdalen
College and replaced them with a wholly Catholic board. The last straw was the
birth of a Catholic heir in 1688, portending a return to a Pre-Reformation
Catholic dynasty.

In what came to be known as the [Glorious
Revolution](/wiki/Glorious_Revolution "Glorious Revolution"), Parliament
deemed James to have abdicated (effectively deposing him, though Parliament
refused to call it that) in favor of his Protestant daughter and son-in-law
and nephew, [Mary II](/wiki/Mary_II_of_England "Mary II of England") and
[William III](/wiki/William_III_of_England "William III of England"). Although
this affair is celebrated as solidifying both English liberties and the
Protestant nature of the kingdom, some argue that it was "fundamentally a coup
spearheaded by a foreign army and navy."[45][46][47]

James fled into exile, and with him many Catholic nobility and gentry. The
[Act of Settlement 1701](/wiki/Act_of_Settlement_1701 "Act of Settlement
1701"), which remains in operation today, established the royal line through
Sophia, Electress of Hanover, and specifically excludes any Catholic or anyone
who marries a Catholic from the throne. This Act was partially changed when
the ban on the monarch's marrying a Catholic was eliminated (along with the
rule of male succession).[48]

[Henry Benedict Stuart](/wiki/Henry_Benedict_Stuart "Henry Benedict Stuart")
(Cardinal-Duke of York), the last [Jacobite](/wiki/Jacobitism "Jacobitism")
heir to publicly assert a claim to the thrones of England, Scotland, and
Ireland, died in Rome in 1807. A [monument to the Royal
Stuarts](/wiki/Monument_to_the_Royal_Stuarts "Monument to the Royal Stuarts")
exists today at Vatican City. [Franz, Duke of
Bavaria](/wiki/Franz,_Duke_of_Bavaria "Franz, Duke of Bavaria"), head of the
[Wittelsbach](/wiki/Wittelsbach "Wittelsbach") family, is the most senior
descendant of King Charles I and is considered by Jacobites to be the heir of
the [Stuarts](/wiki/House_of_Stuart "House of Stuart").[49][50]

### Recusants and moves towards
Emancipation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Recusants and moves towards Emancipation")]

The years from 1688 to the early 19th century were in some respects the nadir
for Catholicism in England. Deprived of their dioceses, four [Apostolic
Vicariates](/wiki/Apostolic_Vicariate "Apostolic Vicariate") were set up
throughout England until the re-establishment of the diocesan episcopacy in
1850. Although the persecution was not violent as in the past, Catholic
numbers, influence and visibility in English society reached their lowest ebb.
Their civil rights were severely curtailed: their right to own property or
inherit land was greatly limited, they were burdened with special taxes, they
could not send their children abroad for Catholic education, they could not
vote, and priests were liable to imprisonment.

There was no longer, as once in Stuart times, any notable Catholic presence at
court, in public life, in the military or professions. Many of the Catholic
nobles and gentry who had preserved on their lands among their tenants small
pockets of Catholicism had followed James into exile, and others, at least
outwardly, conformed to Anglicanism, meaning fewer such Catholic communities
survived intact. A bishop at this time (roughly from 1688 to 1850) was called
a [Vicar apostolic](/wiki/Vicar_apostolic "Vicar apostolic"). A Vicar
Apostolic was a [titular bishop](/wiki/Titular_bishop "Titular bishop") (as
opposed to a diocesan bishop) through whom the pope exercised jurisdiction
over a [particular church](/wiki/Particular_church "Particular church")
territory in England. Interestingly, English-speaking
[colonial](/wiki/Colonial_history_of_the_United_States "Colonial history of
the United States") America came under the jurisdiction of the [Vicar
Apostolic of the London](/wiki/Apostolic_Vicariate_of_the_London_District
"Apostolic Vicariate of the London District"). As [titular
bishop](/wiki/Titular_bishop "Titular bishop") over Catholics in British
America, he was important to the government not only in regard to its English-
speaking North American colonies, but also after the [Seven Years'
War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years' War") when the [British
Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire"), in 1763, acquired the French-
speaking (and predominantly Catholic) territory of Canada. Only after the
[Treaty of Paris](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1783\) "Treaty of Paris \(1783\)")
in 1783 and in 1789 with the consecration of [John
Carroll](/wiki/John_Carroll_\(bishop\) "John Carroll \(bishop\)"), a friend of
[Benjamin Franklin](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin "Benjamin Franklin"), did the U.S.
have its own diocesan bishop, free of the Vicar Apostolic of London, James
Robert Talbot.[51][52][53][54][55]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Distribution_of_English_Recusant_Catholics%2C_1715-1720.png/200px-
Distribution_of_English_Recusant_Catholics%2C_1715-1720.png)](/wiki/File:Distribution_of_English_Recusant_Catholics,_1715-1720.png)

[](/wiki/File:Distribution_of_English_Recusant_Catholics,_1715-1720.png
"Enlarge")

Geographical distribution of English Catholic Recusancy, 1715—1720.

Most Catholics retreated to complete isolation from a popular Protestant
mainstream, and Catholicism in England in this period is politically, if not
socially, invisible to history, [Alexander Pope](/wiki/Alexander_Pope
"Alexander Pope") being one memorable English Catholic of the 18th century and
the other being a member of the Catholic gentry, the [Duke of
Norfolk](/wiki/Duke_of_Norfolk "Duke of Norfolk"), the Premier
[Duke](/wiki/Duke "Duke") in the [peerage](/wiki/Peerage "Peerage") of England
and as [Earl of Arundel](/wiki/Earl_of_Arundel "Earl of Arundel"), the Premier
[Earl](/wiki/Earl "Earl"). In virtue of his status and as head of the [Howard
family](/wiki/Howard_family "Howard family") (which included the [Earl of
Carlisle](/wiki/Earl_of_Carlisle "Earl of Carlisle"), the [Earl of
Suffolk](/wiki/Earl_of_Suffolk "Earl of Suffolk"), the [Earl of
Berkshire](/wiki/Earl_of_Berkshire "Earl of Berkshire"), and the [Earl of
Effingham](/wiki/Earl_of_Effingham "Earl of Effingham")), the Duke was always
at court. Pope, however, seemed to benefit from the isolation. In 1713, when
he was 25, he took subscriptions for a project that filled his life for the
next seven years, the result being a new version of Homer's
[Iliad](/wiki/Iliad "Iliad"). [Samuel Johnson](/wiki/Samuel_Johnson "Samuel
Johnson") pronounced it the greatest translation ever achieved in the English
language.[56] Over time, Pope became the greatest poet of the age, the
[Augustan Age](/wiki/Augustan_poetry "Augustan poetry"), especially for his
mock-heroic poems, [Rape of the Lock](/wiki/Rape_of_the_Lock "Rape of the
Lock") and [The Dunciad](/wiki/The_Dunciad "The Dunciad"). Around this time,
in 1720, [Clement XI](/wiki/Clement_XI "Clement XI") proclaimed Anselm of
Canterbury a [Doctor of the Church](/wiki/Doctor_of_the_Church "Doctor of the
Church"). In 1752, mid-century, Great Britain adopted the [Gregorian
calendar](/wiki/Gregorian_calendar "Gregorian calendar") decreed by Pope
[Gregory XIII](/wiki/Gregory_XIII "Gregory XIII") in 1582. Later in the
century there was some liberalisation of the anti-Catholic laws on the basis
of Enlightenment ideals.

In 1778 a [Catholic Relief Act](/wiki/Papists_Act_1778 "Papists Act 1778")
allowed Catholics to own property, inherit land and join the army. Hardline
Protestant mobs reacted in the [Gordon Riots](/wiki/Gordon_Riots "Gordon
Riots") in 1780, attacking any building in London which was associated with
Catholicism or owned by Catholics. Other reforms allowed the clergy to operate
more openly and thus allowed permanent missions to be set up in the larger
towns. [Stonyhurst College](/wiki/Stonyhurst_College "Stonyhurst College"),
for example, was re-established in 1791 for wealthier Catholics. In 1837,
James Arundel, the tenth Baron Arundel of Wardour, bequeathed to Stonyhurst
the Arundel Library, which contained the vast Arundel family collection,
including some of the school's most important books and manuscripts such as a
Shakespeare [First Folio](/wiki/First_Folio "First Folio") and a manuscript
copy of Froissart's _Chronicles_ , looted from the body of a dead Frenchman
after the [Battle of Agincourt](/wiki/Battle_of_Agincourt "Battle of
Agincourt"). Yet Catholic [recusants](/wiki/Recusants "Recusants") as a whole
remained a small group, except where they stayed the majority religion in
various pockets, notably in rural [Lancashire](/wiki/Lancashire "Lancashire")
and [Cumbria](/wiki/Cumbria "Cumbria"), or were part of the Catholic
aristocracy and squirearchy.[57] One of the most interesting contemporary
descendents of recusants is [Timothy Radcliffe](/wiki/Timothy_Radcliffe
"Timothy Radcliffe"), former Master of the Order of Preachers
([Dominicans](/wiki/Dominican_Order "Dominican Order")) and writer. Radcliffe
is related to three former cardinals—Weld, Vaughan and Hume (the last because
his cousin Lord Hunt is married to Hume's sister), and his family is connected
to many of the great recusant English Catholic families, the Arundels,
Tichbournes, Tablots, Stonors, and Weld-Blundells.[58] Finally, history cannot
forget the famous recusant, [Maria Fitzherbert](/wiki/Maria_Fitzherbert "Maria
Fitzherbert"), who during this period secretly married the [Prince of
Wales](/wiki/Prince_of_Wales "Prince of Wales"), [Prince
Regent](/wiki/Prince_Regent "Prince Regent"), and future [George
IV](/wiki/George_IV "George IV") in 1785. The [British
Constitution](/wiki/British_Constitution "British Constitution"), however, did
not accept it and George IV later moved on. Cast aside by the establishment,
she was adopted by the town of Brighton, whose citizens, both Catholic and
Protestant, called her "Mrs. Prince". According to journalist, Richard Abbott,
"Before the town had a [Catholic] church of its own, she had a priest say Mass
at her own house, and invited local Catholics", suggesting the recusants of
Brighton were not very undiscovered.[59][60]

In a new study of the English Catholic community, 1688–1745, Gabriel Glickman
notes that Catholics, especially those whose social position gave them access
to the courtly centres of power and patronage, had a significant part to play
in 18th-century England. They were not as marginal as one might think today.
For example, Alexander Pope was not the only Catholic whose contributions
(especially, _Essays on Man_) help define the temper of an early English
Enlightenment. In addition to Pope, Glickman notes, a Catholic architect,
[James Gibbs](/wiki/James_Gibbs "James Gibbs"), returned baroque forms to the
London skyline and a Catholic composer, [Thomas Arne](/wiki/Thomas_Arne
"Thomas Arne"), composed "Rule Britannia." According to reviewer Aidan
Bellenger, Glickman also suggests that "rather than being the victims of the
Stuart failure, 'the unpromising setting of exile and defeat' had 'sown the
seed of a frail but resilient English Catholic Enlightenment.'"[61] Yale
University historian Steve Pincus likewise argues in his book, _1688: The
First Modern Revolution_ , that Catholics under William and Mary and their
successors experienced considerable freedom.[62]

### Coming of the Irish and English
converts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Coming of the Irish and English converts")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Statue_Cardinal_Newman%2C_Brompton_Oratory.jpg/200px-
Statue_Cardinal_Newman%2C_Brompton_Oratory.jpg)](/wiki/File:Statue_Cardinal_Newman,_Brompton_Oratory.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Statue_Cardinal_Newman,_Brompton_Oratory.jpg "Enlarge")

Statue of [Cardinal Newman](/wiki/Cardinal_Newman "Cardinal Newman") outside
the Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, London

After this moribund period, the first signs of a revival occurred as thousands
of French Catholics fled France during the [French
Revolution](/wiki/French_Revolution "French Revolution"). The leaders of the
Revolution were virulently anti-Catholic, even singling out priests and nuns
for summary execution or massacre, and England was seen as a safe haven from
[Jacobin](/wiki/Jacobin_\(politics\) "Jacobin \(politics\)") violence. Also
around this time (1801), a new political entity was formed, the [United
Kingdom of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland"), which merged the Kingdom of Great Britain with
the [Kingdom of Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland"), thus
increasing the number of Catholics in the new state. Pressure for abolition of
anti-Catholic laws grew, particularly with the need for Catholic recruits to
fight in the [Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars").
Despite the strong opposition of King [George III](/wiki/George_III "George
III"), which delayed reform, 1829 brought the culmination of the
liberalisation of the anti-Catholic laws.[63] Parliament passed the [Roman
Catholic Relief Act 1829](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Relief_Act_1829 "Roman Catholic
Relief Act 1829"), giving Catholics almost equal civil rights, including the
right to vote and to hold most public offices. If Catholics were rich,
however, exceptions were always made, even before the changes. For example,
American ministers to the [Court of St. James's](/wiki/Court_of_St._James%27s
"Court of St. James's") were often struck by the prominence of wealthy
American-born Catholics, titled ladies among the nobility, like Louisa
(Caton), granddaughter of [Charles Carroll of
Carrollton](/wiki/Charles_Carroll_of_Carrollton "Charles Carroll of
Carrollton"), and her two sisters, Mary Ann and Elizabeth. After Louisa's
first husband (Sir Felton Bathurst-Hervey) died, Louisa later married the
[son](/wiki/Francis_D%27Arcy-Osborne,_7th_Duke_of_Leeds "Francis D'Arcy-
Osborne, 7th Duke of Leeds") of the Duke of Leeds, and had the [Duke of
Wellington](/wiki/Duke_of_Wellington "Duke of Wellington") as her European
protector. Her sister, Mary Ann, married the Marquess of Wellesley, the
brother of the Duke of Wellington; and her other sister, Elizabeth (Lady
Stafford), married another British nobleman.[64][65][66][67] Though British
law required an Anglican marriage service, each of the sisters and their
Protestant spouses had a Catholic ceremony afterwards. At Louisa's first
marriage, the Duke of Wellington escorted the bride.[68]

In the 1840s and 1850s, especially during the [Great Irish
Famine](/wiki/Great_Irish_Famine "Great Irish Famine"), while much of the
large outflow of emigration from Ireland was headed to the United States to
seek work, hundreds of thousands of Irish people also migrated across the
channel to England and Scotland, and established communities in cities there,
including London, [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool "Liverpool"),
[Manchester](/wiki/Manchester "Manchester") and [Glasgow](/wiki/Glasgow
"Glasgow"), but also in towns and villages up and down the country, thus
giving English Catholicism a numerical boost. Also significant was the rise in
the 1830s and 1840s of the [Oxford Movement](/wiki/Oxford_Movement "Oxford
Movement"), which claimed Catholic validity for Anglican orders and sought to
revive some elements of Catholic theology and ritual within the Church of
England (creating [Anglo-Catholicism](/wiki/Anglo-Catholicism "Anglo-
Catholicism")).

A proportion of the Anglicans who were involved in the Oxford Movement or
"Tractarianism" were ultimately led beyond these positions and converted to
the Catholic Church, including, in 1845, the movement's principal intellectual
leader, [John Henry Newman](/wiki/John_Henry_Newman "John Henry Newman"). More
new Catholics would come from the Anglican Church, often via high Anglicanism,
for at least the next hundred years, and something of this continues.

Prominent intellectual and artistic figures who turned to Catholicism in the
19th and 20th centuries included the leading architect of the [Gothic
Revival](/wiki/Gothic_Revival "Gothic Revival"), [Augustus
Pugin](/wiki/Augustus_Pugin "Augustus Pugin"), the artist [Graham
Sutherland](/wiki/Graham_Sutherland "Graham Sutherland") and literary figures
such as Newman, [Gerard Manley Hopkins](/wiki/Gerard_Manley_Hopkins "Gerard
Manley Hopkins"), [G. K. Chesterton](/wiki/G._K._Chesterton "G. K.
Chesterton"), [Ronald Knox](/wiki/Ronald_Knox "Ronald Knox"), [Siegfried
Sassoon](/wiki/Siegfried_Sassoon "Siegfried Sassoon"), [Evelyn
Waugh](/wiki/Evelyn_Waugh "Evelyn Waugh"), [Edith Sitwell](/wiki/Edith_Sitwell
"Edith Sitwell"), [Graham Greene](/wiki/Graham_Greene "Graham Greene") and
[Muriel Spark](/wiki/Muriel_Spark "Muriel Spark").[69] Prominent cradle
Catholics included the film director, [Alfred
Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred Hitchcock"), writers such as
[Hilaire Belloc](/wiki/Hilaire_Belloc "Hilaire Belloc"), [Lord
Acton](/wiki/Lord_Acton "Lord Acton"), and [J. R. R.
Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien") and the composer [Edward
Elgar](/wiki/Edward_Elgar "Edward Elgar"), whose oratorio _[The Dream of
Gerontius](/wiki/The_Dream_of_Gerontius "The Dream of Gerontius")_ was based
on a 19th-century poem by Newman.

At various points after the 16th century hopes have been entertained by many
English Catholics that the "reconversion of England" was near at hand.
Additionally, with the arrival of immigrant masses of Irish Catholics, some
considered that a "second spring" of Catholicism across Britain was
developing. Rome responded by [re-establishing the Catholic hierarchy in
1850](/wiki/Universalis_Ecclesiae "Universalis Ecclesiae"), creating 12
Catholic dioceses in England from existing [apostolic
vicariates](/wiki/Apostolic_vicariates "Apostolic vicariates") and appointing
diocesan bishops (to replace earlier [titular bishops](/wiki/Titular_bishop
"Titular bishop")) with fixed sees on a more traditional Catholic pattern. The
Catholic Church in England and Wales had 22 dioceses immediately before the
Reformation, but none of the current 22 bear close resemblance
(geographically) to those 22 earlier pre-Reformation dioceses.

The re-established diocesan episcopacy specifically avoided using places that
were seats of Church of England dioceses as seats, in effect temporarily
abandoning the titles of Catholic dioceses before Elizabeth I because of the
[Ecclesiastical Titles Act of 1851](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_Titles_Act_of_1851
"Ecclesiastical Titles Act of 1851"), which in England favoured a state church
(i.e., Church of England) and denied arms and legal existence to territorial
Catholic sees on the basis that the state could not grant such "privileges" to
"entities" that allegedly did not exist. Some of the Catholic dioceses,
however, took the titles of bishoprics which had previously existed in England
but were no longer used by the Anglican Church (e.g. Beverley - later divided
into Leeds and Middlesbrough, Hexham - later changed to Hexham and Newcastle).
In the few cases where a Catholic diocese bears the same title as an Anglican
one in the same town or city (e.g. Birmingham, Liverpool, Portsmouth, and
Southwark) — this is the result of the [Church of
England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England") ignoring the prior
existence there of a Catholic see and of the technical repeal of the
Ecclesiastical Titles Act in 1871. Of course, the Act was only carried out in
England. For example, the official recognition afforded by the grant of arms
to the archdiocese of St. Andrews and Edinburgh, brought into being by Lord
Lyon in 1989, was made on the grounds that the Ecclesiastical Titles Act of
1851 never applied to Scotland.[70] In recent times, former Conservative
Cabinent Minister, [John Gummer](/wiki/John_Gummer "John Gummer"), who is a
prominent convert to Catholicism and columnist for the [Catholic
Herald](/wiki/Catholic_Herald "Catholic Herald") in 2007, objected to the fact
that no Catholic diocese can have the same name as an Anglican diocese (such
as London, Canterbury, Durham, etc.) "even though those dioceses had, shall we
say, been borrowed."[71]

### Contemporary English
Catholicism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Contemporary English Catholicism")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Liverpool_Metropolitan_Cathedral_at_dusk_%28reduced_grain%29%2C_corrected_perspective.jpg/200px-
Liverpool_Metropolitan_Cathedral_at_dusk_%28reduced_grain%29%2C_corrected_perspective.jpg)](/wiki/File:Liverpool_Metropolitan_Cathedral_at_dusk_\(reduced_grain\),_corrected_perspective.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Liverpool_Metropolitan_Cathedral_at_dusk_\(reduced_grain\),_corrected_perspective.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral](/wiki/Liverpool_Metropolitan_Cathedral
"Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral"), Liverpool

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Vatican_flag_half-
mast_Oxford_20050403.jpg/220px-Vatican_flag_half-
mast_Oxford_20050403.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vatican_flag_half-
mast_Oxford_20050403.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vatican_flag_half-mast_Oxford_20050403.jpg "Enlarge")

[Oratory Church of St Aloysius
Gonzaga](/wiki/Oratory_Church_of_St_Aloysius_Gonzaga "Oratory Church of St
Aloysius Gonzaga"), Oxford, with the flag of the Vatican City flying at half
staff the day after the death of [Pope John Paul II](/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II
"Pope John Paul II").

English Catholicism continued to grow throughout the first two thirds of the
20th century, when it was associated primarily with elements in the English
intellectual class and the ethnic Irish population. Numbers attending Mass
remained very high in stark contrast with the Anglican church (although not to
other Protestant churches),[72] Clergy numbers, which began the 20th century
at under 3,000, reached a high of 7,500 in 1971.[73]

By the latter years of the twentieth century low numbers of vocations also
affected the church[74] with ordinations to the priesthood dropping from the
hundreds in the late 20th century into the teens in 2006-2011 (16 in 2009 for
example) and a recovery into the 20's thereafter, with a prediction for 2018
of 24.[75][76][77]

As in other English-speaking countries such as the United States and
Australia, the movement of Irish Catholics out of the working-class into the
middle-class suburban mainstream often meant their assimilation with broader,
secular English society and loss of a separate Catholic identity. The [Second
Vatican Council](/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council "Second Vatican Council") has
been followed, as in other Western countries, by divisions between traditional
Catholicism and a more liberal form of Catholicism claiming inspiration from
the Council. This caused difficulties for not a few pre-conciliar converts,
though others have still joined the Church in recent decades (for instance,
[Malcolm Muggeridge](/wiki/Malcolm_Muggeridge "Malcolm Muggeridge") and
[Joseph Pearce](/wiki/Joseph_Pearce "Joseph Pearce")), and public figures
(often descendants of the recusant families) such as [Paul
Johnson](/wiki/Paul_Johnson_\(writer\) "Paul Johnson \(writer\)"); [Peter
Ackroyd](/wiki/Peter_Ackroyd "Peter Ackroyd"); [Antonia
Fraser](/wiki/Antonia_Fraser "Antonia Fraser"); [Mark
Thompson](/wiki/Mark_Thompson_\(television_executive\) "Mark Thompson
\(television executive\)"), [Director General of the
BBC](/wiki/Director_General_of_the_BBC "Director General of the BBC");
[Michael Martin](/wiki/Michael_Martin_\(politician\) "Michael Martin
\(politician\)"), first Catholic to hold the office of
[Speaker](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_House_of_Commons_\(UK\) "Speaker of the House
of Commons \(UK\)") of the [House of
Commons](/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom "House of Commons of the
United Kingdom") since the Reformation; [Chris Patten](/wiki/Chris_Patten
"Chris Patten"), first Catholic to hold the post of
[Chancellor](/wiki/Chancellor "Chancellor") of Oxford since the Reformation;
[Piers Paul Read](/wiki/Piers_Paul_Read "Piers Paul Read"); Helen Liddel,
Britain's High Commissioner to Australia; and former Prime Minister's wife,
[Cherie Blair](/wiki/Cherie_Blair "Cherie Blair"), have no difficulty making
their Catholicism known in public life. The former Prime Minister, [Tony
Blair](/wiki/Tony_Blair "Tony Blair"), was received into full communion with
the Catholic Church in 2007.[78] Catherine Pepinster, Editor of _Tablet_ ,
notes: "The impact of Irish immigrants is one. There are numerous prominent
campaigners, academics, entertainers (like [Danny Boyle](/wiki/Danny_Boyle
"Danny Boyle") the most successful Catholic in showbiz owing to his film,
_Slumdog Millionaire_), politicians and writers. But the descendants of the
[recusant](/wiki/Recusant "Recusant") families are still a force in the
land."[79][80][81]

Since the Council the Church in England has tended to focus on ecumenical
dialogue with the Anglican Church rather than winning converts from it as in
the past.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] However, the 1990s have seen a number of
conversions from Anglicanism to the Catholic Church, largely prompted by the
Church of England's decision to ordain women as priests (among other moves
away from traditional doctrines and structures).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
resultant converts included members of the Royal Family ([Katharine, Duchess
of Kent](/wiki/Katharine,_Duchess_of_Kent "Katharine, Duchess of Kent"), her
son [Lord Nicholas Windsor](/wiki/Lord_Nicholas_Windsor "Lord Nicholas
Windsor") and her grandson [Baron Downpatrick](/wiki/Baron_Downpatrick "Baron
Downpatrick")), a number of Anglican priests. Converts to Catholicism in
Britain, for this reason, tend to be more conservative and even
[traditionalist](/wiki/Traditionalist_Catholic "Traditionalist Catholic") than
Catholics on the European mainland, often opposing trends within the Catholic
Church similar to those which induced them to abandon Anglicanism in the first
place.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

The spirit of ecumenism fostered by Vatican II resulted in 1990 with the
Catholic Church in England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland, joining [Churches
Together in Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/Churches_Together_in_Britain_and_Ireland "Churches Together in
Britain and Ireland") as an expression of the churches' commitment to work
ecumenically. Recently, for example, a memorial was put up to St [John
Houghton](/wiki/John_Houghton_\(martyr\) "John Houghton \(martyr\)") and
fellow [Carthusian](/wiki/Carthusian "Carthusian") monks martyred at the
[London Charterhouse](/wiki/London_Charterhouse "London Charterhouse"), 1535.
Anglican priest, Geoffrey Curtis, campaigned for it with the current
Archbishop of Canterbury's blessing.[82] Also, in another ecumenical gesture,
a plaque in Holywell Street, Oxford, now commemorates the Catholic martyrs of
England. It reads: "Near this spot [George
Nichols](/wiki/George_Nichols_\(martyr\) "George Nichols \(martyr\)"),
[Richard Yaxley](/wiki/Richard_Yaxley "Richard Yaxley"), [Thomas
Belson](/wiki/Thomas_Belson "Thomas Belson"), and [Humphrey
Pritchard](/wiki/Humphrey_Pritchard "Humphrey Pritchard") were executed for
their Catholic faith, 5 July 1589."[83] And at Lambeth Palace, in February
2009, the Archbishop of Canterbury hosted a reception to launch a book, _Why
Go To Church?_ , by Fr [Timothy Radcliffe](/wiki/Timothy_Radcliffe "Timothy
Radcliffe") OP, one of Britain's best known religious and the former master of
the [Dominican Order](/wiki/Dominican_Order "Dominican Order"). A large number
of young Dominican [friars](/wiki/Friars "Friars") attended. Fr Radcliffe
said, "I don't think there have been so many Dominicans in one place since the
time of Robert Kilwardby, the Dominican Archbishop of Canterbury in the 13th
century."[84]

The Church's principles of social justice influenced initiatives to tackle the
challenges of poverty and social inclusion. In Southampton, Fr Pat Murphy
O'Connor founded the St Dismas Society as an agency to meet the needs of ex-
prisoners discharged from Winchester prison. Some of St Dismas Society's early
members went on to help found the Simon Community in Sussex then in London.
Their example gave new inspiration to other clergy, such as the Revd Kenneth
Leech (CofE) of [St Anne's Church, Soho](/wiki/St_Anne%27s_Church,_Soho "St
Anne's Church, Soho") who helped found the homeless charity
[Centrepoint](/wiki/Centrepoint_\(charity\) "Centrepoint \(charity\)"), and
the Revd Bruce Kenrick (Church of Scotland) who helped found the homeless
charity [Shelter](/wiki/Shelter_\(charity\) "Shelter \(charity\)"). In 1986
Cardinal [Basil Hume](/wiki/Basil_Hume "Basil Hume") established the Cardinal
Hume Centre[85] to work with homeless young people, badly housed families and
local communities to access accommodation, support and advice, education,
training and employment opportunities.

In 2006 Cardinal [Cormac Murphy-O'Connor](/wiki/Cormac_Murphy-O%27Connor
"Cormac Murphy-O'Connor") instituted an annual Mass in Support of Migrant
Workers[86] at Westminster Cathedral in partnership with the ethnic chaplains
of Brentwood, Southwark and Westminster.

##
Organisation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Organisation")]

The Catholic Church in England and Wales has five
[provinces](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_province "Ecclesiastical province"):
Birmingham, Cardiff, Liverpool, Southwark and Westminster. There are 22
[dioceses](/wiki/Diocese "Diocese") which are divided into
[parishes](/wiki/Parish "Parish") (for comparison, the Church of England and
Church in Wales currently have a total of 50 dioceses). In addition to these,
there are four dioceses covering England and Wales for specific groups which
are the [Bishopric of the Forces](/wiki/Bishopric_of_the_Forces "Bishopric of
the Forces"), the [Eparchy for
Ukrainians](/wiki/Ukrainian_Catholic_Eparchy_of_Holy_Family_of_London
"Ukrainian Catholic Eparchy of Holy Family of London"), the [Syro-Malabar
Catholic Eparchy of Great Britain](/wiki/Syro-
Malabar_Catholic_Eparchy_of_Great_Britain "Syro-Malabar Catholic Eparchy of
Great Britain") and the [Personal Ordinariate for former
Anglicans](/wiki/Personal_Ordinariate_of_Our_Lady_of_Walsingham "Personal
Ordinariate of Our Lady of Walsingham").

The Catholic bishops in England and Wales come together in a collaborative
structure known as the Bishops' Conference. Currently the [Archbishop of
Westminster](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Westminster "Archbishop of Westminster"),
[Vincent Gerard Nichols](/wiki/Vincent_Gerard_Nichols "Vincent Gerard
Nichols"), is the [President](/wiki/President "President") of the Bishops'
Conference. For this reason in the global Catholic Church (outside England),
he is _de facto_ Primate of England though not in the eyes of English law and
the established Church of England. Historically, the avoidance of the title of
"Primate" was to eschew whipping up anti-Catholic tension, in the same way the
bishops of the restored hierarchy avoided using current titles of Anglican
sees (Archbishop of Westminster rather than "Canterbury" or "London").
However, the Archbishop of Westminster had certain privileges: he was the only
metropolitan in the country until 1911 (when the archdioceses of Birmingham
and Liverpool were created) and he has always acted as leader at meetings of
the English bishops.

Although the bishops of the restored hierarchy took new titles, such as that
of Westminster, they saw themselves very much in continuity with the pre-
Reformation Church. Westminster in particular saw itself as the continuation
of Canterbury, hence the similarity of the [coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms
"Coat of arms") of the two sees (with Westminster believing it has more right
to it since it features the [pallium](/wiki/Pallium "Pallium"), no longer
given to Anglican archbishops). At the back of Westminster Cathedral is a
[list of Popes](/wiki/List_of_Popes "List of Popes") and, alongside this, a
list of Catholic Archbishops of Canterbury beginning with [Augustine of
Canterbury](/wiki/Augustine_of_Canterbury "Augustine of Canterbury") and the
year they received the pallium. After Cardinal Pole, the last Catholic
incumbent of Canterbury, the names of the Catholic vicars apostolic or titular
bishops (from 1685) are recorded and then the Archbishops of Westminster, in
one unimpaired line, from 597 to the present, according to the Archdiocese of
Westminster.[87][88] To highlight this continuity or unimpaired line today,
the installation rites of pre-Reformation Catholic Archbishops of Canterbury
and earlier Archbishops of Westminster were used at the installation of the
current Cardinal Archbishop of Westminster, Vincent Gerard
Nichols.[89][90][91] He became the forty-third of [English
cardinals](/wiki/List_of_English_cardinals "List of English cardinals") since
the 12th century.

### Ordinariate of Our Lady of
Walsingham[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Ordinariate of Our Lady of Walsingham")]

Main article: [Ordinariate of Our Lady of
Walsingham](/wiki/Ordinariate_of_Our_Lady_of_Walsingham "Ordinariate of Our
Lady of Walsingham")

In October 2009, following closed-circuit talks between some Anglicans and the
[Holy See](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See"), Pope Benedict made a relatively
unconditional offer to accommodate disaffected Anglicans in the Church of
England, enabling them, for the first time, to retain parts of their liturgy
and heritage under _[Anglicanorum coetibus](/wiki/Anglicanorum_coetibus
"Anglicanorum coetibus")_ , while being in full communion with Rome. By April
2012 the ordinariate numbered about 1200, including five bishops and 60
priests.[92][93] The ordinariate has recruited a group of aristocrats as
honorary vice-presidents to help out. These include the Duke of Norfolk, the
Countess of Oxford and Asquith and the Duchess of Somerset. Other vice-
presidents include Lord Nicholas Windsor, Sir Josslyn Gore-Booth and the
Squire de Lisle, whose ancestor [Ambrose de Lisle](/wiki/Ambrose_de_Lisle
"Ambrose de Lisle") was a 19th-century Catholic convert who advocated the
corporate reunion of the Anglican Church with Rome. According to the group
leader, Mgr Keith Newton, the ordinariate will "work on something with an
Anglican flavour, but they are not bringing over any set of Anglican
liturgy."[94] The director of music at Westminster Abbey (Anglican), lay
Catholic James O'Donnell, likens the ordinariate to a Uniate church or one of
the many non-Latin Catholic rites, saying: "This is a good opportunity for us
to remember that there isn't a one size fits all, and that this could be a
good moment to adopt the famous civil service philosophy - 'celebrating
diversity'."[95] In May 2013, a former Anglican priest, Alan Hopes, was
appointed the new Bishop of East Anglia, whose diocese includes the Shrine of
Our Lady of Walsingham.[96]

### Eastern Catholic
rites[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Eastern Catholic rites")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Wolverhampton_Ukrainian_Catholic_Church.jpg/220px-
Wolverhampton_Ukrainian_Catholic_Church.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wolverhampton_Ukrainian_Catholic_Church.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wolverhampton_Ukrainian_Catholic_Church.jpg "Enlarge")

A [Ukrainian Greek Catholic](/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church "Ukrainian
Greek Catholic Church") parish church in [Wolverhampton](/wiki/Wolverhampton
"Wolverhampton"), England

There exists the [Apostolic Exarchate for
Ukrainians](/wiki/Apostolic_Exarchate_for_Ukrainians "Apostolic Exarchate for
Ukrainians") which serves the 15,000 Ukrainian Greek Catholics in Great
Britain, with a cathedral and various churches across the country.

The Lebanese Maronite Order (LMO) runs in England and Wales. The LMO is an
order of the [Maronite Catholic Church](/wiki/Maronite_Catholic_Church
"Maronite Catholic Church"), serving Maronite Catholics in England and Wales.
The Revd Augustine Aoun is the parish priest for Maronites. The LMO runs a few
churches, for example Our Lady of Sorrows in Paddington and Our Lady of
Lebanon in Swiss Cottage.

There are also Catholic chaplains of the Eritrean, Chaldean, Syriac, Syro-
Malabar, Syro-Malankara, and Melkite Rites. For information about the Syro-
Malabar chaplaincy within the [Diocese of
Westminster](/wiki/Diocese_of_Westminster "Diocese of Westminster") in London,
see [Syro-Malabar Catholic Church of London](/wiki/Syro-
Malabar_Catholic_Church_of_London "Syro-Malabar Catholic Church of London").

Mass in the Syro-Malabar rite is celebrated each Sunday in St Joseph's
Catholic Church, New Zealand Road, Cardiff.

##
Demography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Demography")]

### General
statistics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: General statistics")]

Migration from Ireland in the 19th and 20th centuries and more recent [Eastern
European](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe") migration have significantly
increased the numbers of Catholics in England and Wales. While figures for
England and Wales alone are difficult to estimate, the ethnic make-up of the
Catholic population in the UK (which includes Northern Irish as British) in
2008 was as follows :[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[White British](/wiki/White_British "White British") | 74.6%  
---|---  
White Eastern European | 9.5%  
[White Irish](/wiki/Irish_migration_to_Great_Britain "Irish migration to Great Britain") | 4.4%  
[White Other](/wiki/Other_White_\(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category\) "Other White \(United Kingdom ethnicity category\)") | 3.9%  
[Black African](/wiki/Black_African "Black African") | 2.5%  
[Mixed](/wiki/Mixed_\(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category\) "Mixed \(United Kingdom ethnicity category\)") other | 1.9%  
[Afro-Caribbean](/wiki/British_African-Caribbean_community "British African-Caribbean community")/Other | 1.7%  
[Asian](/wiki/British_Asian "British Asian") | 1.5%  
  
The White Eastern European members are mainly from [Poland](/wiki/Poland
"Poland"), with smaller numbers from [Lithuania](/wiki/Lithuania "Lithuania"),
[Latvia](/wiki/Latvia "Latvia"), and [Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia").
