[Catholicism portal](/wiki/Portal:Catholicism "Portal:Catholicism")  
  
  * [v](/wiki/Template:Catholic_Church_by_country "Template:Catholic Church by country")
  * [t](/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_Church_by_country "Template talk:Catholic Church by country")
  * [e](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_Church_by_country&action=edit)

  
  
Polish-speaking Catholics first arrived in England in some numbers after the
[partitions of Poland](/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland "Partitions of Poland")
during the 19th century. One of the most notable Poles at this time, who
eventually settled in England, was [Joseph Conrad](/wiki/Joseph_Conrad "Joseph
Conrad"). At the end of the Second World War, many Polish servicemen were
unable to return to their homeland following the imposition of a communist
regime hostile to their return, and the [Polish Resettlement
Corps](/wiki/Polish_Resettlement_Corps "Polish Resettlement Corps") was formed
by the British government to ease their transition into British life. They
were joined by several thousand Displaced Persons (DPs), many were their
family members. This influx of Poles gave rise to the 1947 Polish Resettlement
Act which allowed approximately 250,000 Polish Servicemen and their
dependents, to settle in Britain. [Many assimilated](/wiki/Polish_British
"Polish British") into existing Catholic congregations. According to the
Polish Catholic Mission in England and Wales[97] in 1948 the Catholic
hierarchy in England Wales agreed the appointment of a vicar delegate,
nominated by the Polish Episcopate, with ordinary power over the Polish clergy
and laity throughout England and Wales with certain exceptions relating to
marriage. Subsequently, whenever a Polish Catholic community emerges within
England and Wales, the vicar delegate appoints a Polish priest to organise a
local branch of the Polish Catholic Mission. A priest thus appointed is the
priest in charge, not a parish priest. There are no Polish parishes or
quasiparishes in England and Wales (in accordance with Canons 515 §1 and 516
§1) with the exception of the church at Devonia Road in London. A Polish
Community is sometimes referred to as a "parish" but is not a parish in the
canonical sense. Hence the Community is not a juridical person. The canonical
juridical personality which represents the interests of all Polish Communities
is vested in the Polish Catholic Mission.[98]

Since the 2004 [accession of Poland to the European
Union](/wiki/Accession_of_Poland_to_the_European_Union "Accession of Poland to
the European Union") there has been further large-scale Polish [immigration to
the
UK](/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_Kingdom_\(1922-present_day\)#European_Union
"Immigration to the United Kingdom \(1922-present day\)"). Currently the
Polish Catholic Mission includes around 219 parishes and pastoral centres with
114 priests.[99] The current rector of the Polish Catholic Mission is Rev.
Stefan Wylężek. In Poland, the Polish Bishops Conference has a delegate with
special responsibility for émigré Poles. The current postholder is Bishop
Ryszard Karpiński. [The Tablet](/wiki/The_Tablet "The Tablet") reported in
December 2007 that the Polish Catholic Mission says these parishes follow a
pastoral programme set by the Polish conference of bishops and are viewed as
"an integral part of the Polish church".[100]

In December 2007 Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor said "I'm quite concerned
that Poles are creating a separate Church in Britain – I would want them to be
part of the Catholic life of this country. I would hope those responsible for
the Polish Church here, and the Poles themselves, will be aware that they
should become a part of local parishes as soon as possible when they learn
enough of the language." Mgr Kukla stressed that the Polish Catholic Mission
continues to have a "good relationship" with the hierarchy in England and
Wales and said "Integration is a long process."[101]

Significantly, the Polish Mission co-operated fully with the English
hierarchy's recent research enquiry into the needs of migrants in London's
catholic community. "The Ground of Justice"[102] report by Francis Davis[103]
and Jolanta Stanke _et al._ Von Hügel Institute[104] at [St Edmund's College,
Cambridge](/wiki/St_Edmund%27s_College,_Cambridge "St Edmund's College,
Cambridge") was commissioned by [Archbishop Kevin
McDonald](/wiki/Archbishop_Kevin_McDonald "Archbishop Kevin McDonald") of
Southwark, and [Bishop Thomas McMahon](/wiki/Thomas_McMahon_\(bishop\) "Thomas
McMahon \(bishop\)") of Brentwood. 1000 people attending Mass in three London
dioceses were surveyed using anonymous questionnaires available in Polish,
Lithuanian, Chinese, French, Spanish, Portuguese, and English. The
congregations were from mainstream Diocesan parishes, ethnic chaplaincies, and
churches of the Polish Vicariate. The report findings described how 86% of
eastern Europeans said the availability of Mass in their mother tongue was a
reason for their choosing to worship in a particular church. The report's
recommendations emphasised cooperation with key overseas bishops conferences,
dioceses, and [religious institutes](/wiki/Religious_institute "Religious
institute") on the recruitment and appointment of ethnic chaplains; the
recognition of language skills as a legitimate training activity and cost for
seminarians, clergy, parish volunteer and lay employees; and the consolidation
of dispersed charitable funds for pastoral development and the poor in
London.[105]

## Adoption
controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Adoption controversy")]

On November 3, 2016, John Bingham reported in The Daily Telegraph that
Cardinal [Vincent Nichols](/wiki/Vincent_Nichols "Vincent Nichols") officially
acknowledged that the Catholic Church in England and Wales had pressured
young, unmarried mothers in the country to put their children up for adoption
in agencies linked to the Catholic Church throughout the decades following
World War II and offered an apology.[106]

##
Miracles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Miracles")]

A number of events which Catholics hold to be [miracles](/wiki/Miracles
"Miracles") are associated with England.

### Marian
apparitions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Marian apparitions")]

A number of [Marian apparitions](/wiki/Marian_apparitions "Marian
apparitions") are associated with England, the best known are the following;

  * [Our Lady of Mount Carmel](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Mount_Carmel "Our Lady of Mount Carmel"), associated with [Simon Stock](/wiki/Simon_Stock "Simon Stock") at [Aylesford](/wiki/Aylesford "Aylesford")
  * [Our Lady of Walsingham](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Walsingham "Our Lady of Walsingham"), associated with [Richeldis de Faverches](/wiki/Richeldis_de_Faverches "Richeldis de Faverches") at [Walsingham](/wiki/Walsingham "Walsingham")
  * Our Lady of the [Immaculate Conception](/wiki/Immaculate_Conception "Immaculate Conception"), associated with Helsim the Abbot in the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea")
  * Our Lady of Evesham, associated with [Egwin of Evesham](/wiki/Egwin_of_Evesham "Egwin of Evesham") at [Evesham](/wiki/Evesham "Evesham")
  * Our Lady of Canterbury, associated with [Dunstan](/wiki/Dunstan "Dunstan") and [Anselm](/wiki/Anselm_of_Canterbury "Anselm of Canterbury") at [Canterbury](/wiki/Canterbury "Canterbury")
  * Our Lady of London, associated with [Thomas a Becket](/wiki/Thomas_a_Becket "Thomas a Becket") and [Hildegard von Bingen](/wiki/Hildegard_von_Bingen "Hildegard von Bingen") at [London](/wiki/London "London")
  * Our Lady of Jervaulx, associated with Abbot John Kingston of Byland at [Jervaulx](/wiki/Jervaulx_Abbey "Jervaulx Abbey")
  * Our Lady of Durham, associated with [Godric of Finchale](/wiki/Godric_of_Finchale "Godric of Finchale") at [Durham](/wiki/Durham,_England "Durham, England")
  * [Our Lady of Ipswich](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Ipswich "Our Lady of Ipswich"), associated with Anne Wentworth at [Ipswich](/wiki/Ipswich "Ipswich")

###
Incorruptibility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Incorruptibility")]

A number of cases of alleged [incorruptibility](/wiki/Incorruptibility
"Incorruptibility") of some Catholic saints are associated with England;

  * [Æthelthryth](/wiki/%C3%86thelthryth "Æthelthryth") of Ely, hand discovered in 1811
  * [Cuthbert of Lindisfarne](/wiki/Cuthbert_of_Lindisfarne "Cuthbert of Lindisfarne"), relics destroyed under Henry VIII
  * [Werburgh](/wiki/Werburgh "Werburgh") of Chester, relics destroyed under Henry VIII
  * [Wihtburh](/wiki/Wihtburh "Wihtburh") of East Anglia, relics destroyed under Henry VIII
  * [Winibald](/wiki/Winibald "Winibald") of Wessex, tomb found empty in 1968
  * [Guthlac of Crowland](/wiki/Guthlac_of_Crowland "Guthlac of Crowland"), relics destroyed by Vikings
  * [Ælfheah of Canterbury](/wiki/%C3%86lfheah_of_Canterbury "Ælfheah of Canterbury"), buried at Canterbury Cathedral
  * [Edward the Confessor](/wiki/Edward_the_Confessor "Edward the Confessor"), bodily allegedly intact in 1269, skeleton by 1685
  * [Hugh of Lincoln](/wiki/Hugh_of_Lincoln "Hugh of Lincoln"), tomb pillaged in 1364, shrine destroyed under Henry VIII
  * [Edmund of Abingdon](/wiki/Edmund_of_Abingdon "Edmund of Abingdon"), taken to [Pontigny Abbey](/wiki/Pontigny_Abbey "Pontigny Abbey") in France
  * [John Southworth](/wiki/John_Southworth_\(martyr\) "John Southworth \(martyr\)"), returned to [Westminster Cathedral](/wiki/Westminster_Cathedral "Westminster Cathedral") in 1927

###
Stigmata[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church_in_England_and_Wales&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Stigmata")]

Two cases of alleged [stigmata](/wiki/Stigmata "Stigmata") are associated with
England, neither have been approved by the Vatican;

  * 1880: [Teresa Helena Higginson](/wiki/Teresa_Helena_Higginson "Teresa Helena Higginson"), at [Gainsborough, Lincolnshire](/wiki/Gainsborough,_Lincolnshire "Gainsborough, Lincolnshire")
  * 1986: Patricia de Menezes, at [Surrey](/wiki/Surrey "Surrey")

  2. **Jump up ^** <http://www.newadvent.org/cathen> The _[Catholic Encyclopedia](/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia "Catholic Encyclopedia")_ says this: "Before the breach with Rome under Henry VIII there was absolutely no doctrinal difference between the faith of Englishmen and the rest of Catholic Christendom, and 'Anglicanism,' as connoting a separate or independent religious system, was unknown. The name 'Ecclesia Anglicana,' or English Church, was of course employed, but always in the Catholic and Papal use of the term as signifying that part of the one Catholic Church under the jurisdiction of the Pope which was situated in England, and precisely in the same way as the Church in Scotland was called the 'Ecclesia Scotticana,' the Church in France, the 'Ecclesia Gallicana,' and the Church in Spain the 'Ecclesia Hispanica.' That such national or regional appellations were a part of the style of the Roman Curia itself, and that they in no sense could have implied any indication of independence from Rome, is sufficiently well known to all who are familiar with pre-Reformation records."

  39. **Jump up ^** Kevin Phillips _The Cousins ' Wars_ (New York: Basic Books, 1999, 52–3. Phillips says this: "Religious historians beg off from stating firm numbers for either camp. If Puritans probably represented 10–20 percent of the national population, most of them still worshiping within the Church of England, Catholics were much harder to count. Open 'recusants' – Catholics who paid fines to avoid attending the Church of England – numbered sixty thousand in 1640. Many more, however, reluctantly attended services on Sunday with scowls or for as short a time as possible. The more identifiable of these were called 'Church Papists'; the less important, ordinary grumblers who merely talked of preferring the older ceremonies were uncountable. In the north and west, at least half the population outside the towns were Catholic to some degree. By this broad definition, Catholics would have numbered 10–15 percent of the total English population. Practicing Catholics, however, could not have been more than 2–3 percent. Catholicism survived most strongly among the nobility, of whom 15–20 percent clung to the old faith, including many leading magnates in an arc from Cumberland, Westmoreland, and Lancashire south to Derby, Worchestershire, and Hereforshire. However, even solidly Protestant East Anglian counties like Suffolk and Essex each had three, four, or a half-dozen aristocratic families holding to the religion of their forebears. This is perhaps one reason why the populace took Catholic 'plots' so seriously: What they called popery was especially visible among the powerful and influential."

qa.question: when were catholic churches allowed back in england
qa.answer: ['Dioceses (replacing districts) were re-established by Pope Pius IX in 1850']

nq_199_28.Query Analysis: The query asks for the time period when Catholic churches were allowed to re-establish themselves in England after a period of prohibition or restriction.
nq_199_28.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that Catholic dioceses were re-established by Pope Pius IX in 1850, which implies that this is the time when Catholic churches were officially allowed back in England.
nq_199_28.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the religious landscape of England, focusing on the Anglican Church, the treatment of dissenters, and the historical context of Roman Catholics in England. It mentions the continued official suspicion and legal restrictions against Roman Catholics well into the 19th century.
nq_199_28.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Roman Catholics' and '19th century', which are relevant to the query.
nq_199_28.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document does not explicitly mention 'Pope Pius IX' or '1850'.
nq_199_28.Key Information Matching: The document provides historical context about the treatment of Roman Catholics in England, including their dwindling population and continued restrictions into the 19th century, which is relevant to understanding the period leading up to the re-establishment of Catholic churches.
